羅生門: 芥川龍之介
Rashomon: Akutagawa Ryunosuke

羅生門: ある日の暮方の事である。
Rashomon: It happened one evening.

羅生門: 一人の下人が、羅生門の下で雨やみを待っていた。
Rashomon: A lowly servant was under Rashōmon Gate, waiting for the rain to stop.

羅生門: 広い門の下には、この男のほかに誰もいない。
Rashomon: Under the broad gate, there was no one but him.

羅生門: ただ、所々丹塗の剥げた、大きな円柱に、蟋蟀が一匹とまっている。
Rashomon: On one of the large round pillars whose red paint was peeling off in places, there was only a solitary katydid.

羅生門: 羅生門が、朱雀大路にある以上は、この男のほかにも、雨やみをする市女笠や揉烏帽子が、もう二三人はありそうなものである。
Rashomon: Because the gate was located on Suzaku Boulevard, you would normally expect to find two or three other people there, waiting for the rain to let up.

羅生門: それが、この男のほかには誰もいない。
Rashomon: But there was nobody there but him.

羅生門: 何故かと云うと、この二三年、京都には、地震とか辻風とか火事とか饑饉とか云う災がつづいて起った。
Rashomon: You see, over the last two or three years there had been a series of disasters in Kyoto: earthquakes, whirlwinds, fires, and famines.

羅生門: そこで洛中のさびれ方は一通りではない。
Rashomon: The capital was falling apart in many different ways.

羅生門: 旧記によると、仏像や仏具を打砕いて、その丹がついたり、金銀の箔がついたりした木を、路ばたにつみ重ねて、薪の料に売っていたと云う事である。
Rashomon: According to old records, Buddhist statues and altars had been smashed, and their vermilion-lacquered and gold- or silver-foiled wood piled up on the side of the road and sold as kindling.

羅生門: 洛中がその始末であるから、羅生門の修理などは、元より誰も捨てて顧る者がなかった。
Rashomon: Needless to say, with the capital in this condition, there was no one to repair the gate, and indeed, nobody even gave it a second thought.

羅生門: するとその荒れ果てたのをよい事にして、狐狸が棲む。
Rashomon: Taking advantage of this state of neglect, foxes and badgers began to live there.

羅生門: 盗人が棲む。
Rashomon: Robbers lived there.

羅生門: とうとうしまいには、引取り手のない死人を、この門へ持って来て、棄てて行くと云う習慣さえ出来た。
Rashomon: Eventually, it had even become customary to take unclaimed corpses to the gate and dump them there.

羅生門: そこで、日の目が見えなくなると、誰でも気味を悪るがって、この門の近所へは足ぶみをしない事になってしまったのである。
Rashomon: So after sunset, people got scared, and nobody dared set foot near the gate after dark.

羅生門: その代りまた鴉がどこからか、たくさん集って来た。
Rashomon: In their place, a large murder of crows had flocked there.

羅生門: 昼間見ると、その鴉が何羽となく輪を描いて、高い鴟尾のまわりを啼きながら、飛びまわっている。
Rashomon: During the day, countless birds could be seen flying around in circles while cawing at the high ornamental ridge-end tiles.

羅生門: ことに門の上の空が、夕焼けであかくなる時には、それが胡麻をまいたようにはっきり見えた。
Rashomon: They looked just like scattered sesame seeds, particularly when the sky above the gate turned red at sunset.

羅生門: 鴉は、勿論、門の上にある死人の肉を、啄みに来るのである。
Rashomon: The crows, of course, had come to peck at the flesh of the dead bodies on top of the gate.

羅生門: ――もっとも今日は、刻限が遅いせいか、一羽も見えない。
Rashomon: Today, however, perhaps because it was late, not a single bird could be seen.

羅生門: ただ、所々、崩れかかった、そうしてその崩れ目に長い草のはえた石段の上に、鴉の糞が、点々と白くこびりついているのが見える。
Rashomon: But what you could see were their white droppings, stuck in patches to the stone steps, which were crumbling in places, with long weeds growing from the cracks.

羅生門: 下人は七段ある石段の一番上の段に、洗いざらした紺の襖の尻を据えて、右の頬に出来た、大きな面皰を気にしながら、ぼんやり、雨のふるのを眺めていた。
Rashomon: The servant, wearing a navy-blue kimono that had faded from over-washing, sat down on the seventh-and-top step of the stone staircase.

羅生門: 作者はさっき、「下人が雨やみを待っていた」と書いた。
Rashomon: He watched the rain fall while playing with a large pimple on his right cheek, lost in his own thoughts.

羅生門: しかし、下人は雨がやんでも、格別どうしようと云う当てはない。
Rashomon: A little while ago, I wrote, "A lowly servant was waiting for the rain to stop".

羅生門: ふだんなら、勿論、主人の家へ帰る可き筈である。
Rashomon: However, even if the rain did stop, the servant still wouldn't have anything to do.

羅生門: 所がその主人からは、四五日前に暇を出された。
Rashomon: Normally, of course, he would have been expected to return to his master's house, but he had been released from the service of his master four or five days before.

羅生門: 前にも書いたように、当時京都の町は一通りならず衰微していた。
Rashomon: As I wrote earlier, at this time, the city of Kyoto was deteriorating in many different ways.

羅生門: 今この下人が、永年、使われていた主人から、暇を出されたのも、実はこの衰微の小さな余波にほかならない。
Rashomon: That this servant had been dismissed by his master, who had employed him for so many years, was merely another small side effect of this decline.

羅生門: だから「下人が雨やみを待っていた」と云うよりも「雨にふりこめられた下人が、行き所がなくて、途方にくれていた」と云う方が、適当である。
Rashomon: So, rather than saying, "A lowly servant was waiting for the rain to stop", it would have been more appropriate to say, "A lowly servant, trapped by the rain, had nowhere to go, and didn't know what to do".

羅生門: その上、今日の空模様も少からず、この平安朝の下人の Sentimentalisme に影響した。
Rashomon: The weather that day further served to darken the mood of this Heian-period servant.

羅生門: 申の刻下りからふり出した雨は、いまだに上るけしきがない。
Rashomon: The rain had started falling at a little after 4 PM, and it still showed no signs of letting up.

羅生門: そこで、下人は、何をおいても差当り明日の暮しをどうにかしようとして――云わばどうにもならない事を、どうにかしようとして、とりとめもない考えをたどりながら、さっきから朱雀大路にふる雨の音を、聞くともなく聞いていたのである。
Rashomon: For now, foremost on the servant's mind was how he would make his living tomorrow—how he would get through this "hopeless situation". As he tried to piece together his wandering thoughts, he listened pensively to the sound of the rain falling on Suzaku Boulevard.

羅生門: 雨は、羅生門をつつんで、遠くから、ざあっと云う音をあつめて来る。
Rashomon: The rain engulfed Rashōmon, and gales of rain from far away pounded down upon the gate with a tremendous noise.

羅生門: 夕闇は次第に空を低くして、見上げると、門の屋根が、斜につき出した甍の先に、重たくうす暗い雲を支えている。
Rashomon: The darkness of night gradually set in from above, and if you were to look up, it might seem as if the large, gloomy clouds were suspended from the ends of the tiles that jutted out from the roof of the gate.

羅生門: どうにもならない事を、どうにかするためには、手段を選んでいる遑はない。
Rashomon: In order to somehow get through his "hopeless situation", the servant might have to set his morals aside.

羅生門: 選んでいれば、築土の下か、道ばたの土の上で、饑死をするばかりである。
Rashomon: If he refused to do things that he thought were morally questionable, then he would only end up starving to death under a roofed mud wall or on the side of the road.

羅生門: そうして、この門の上へ持って来て、犬のように棄てられてしまうばかりである。
Rashomon: And then he would be taken to this gate, to be discarded, like a dog.

羅生門: 選ばないとすれば――下人の考えは、何度も同じ道を低徊した揚句に、やっとこの局所へ逢着した。
Rashomon: "If I am willing to do whatever it takes to survive…" His thoughts had circled through his head a number of times, and they had finally arrived here.

羅生門: しかしこの「すれば」は、いつまでたっても、結局「すれば」であった。
Rashomon: But this "if" would always remain a mere hypothetical.

羅生門: 下人は、手段を選ばないという事を肯定しながらも、この「すれば」のかたをつけるために、当然、その後に来る可き「盗人になるよりほかに仕方がない」と云う事を、積極的に肯定するだけの、勇気が出ずにいたのである。
Rashomon: For although the servant acknowledged that he had to do whatever he could to get by, he didn't have the courage to bring the sentence to its foregone conclusion: "I am bound to become a thief."

羅生門: 下人は、大きな嚔をして、それから、大儀そうに立上った。
Rashomon: The servant sneezed, and he stood up wearily.

羅生門: 夕冷えのする京都は、もう火桶が欲しいほどの寒さである。
Rashomon: Kyoto—so chilly in the evening—was already cold enough that he wished he had a brazier.

羅生門: 風は門の柱と柱との間を、夕闇と共に遠慮なく、吹きぬける。
Rashomon: The wind and the darkness blew mercilessly between the pillars of the gate.

羅生門: 丹塗の柱にとまっていた蟋蟀も、もうどこかへ行ってしまった。
Rashomon: The katydid that had been sitting on the red pillar was long gone.

羅生門: 下人は、頸をちぢめながら、山吹の汗袗に重ねた、紺の襖の肩を高くして門のまわりを見まわした。
Rashomon: The servant tucked his head into his chest, hunched up his shoulders—clad in the blue kimono he wore over his thin yellow underclothes—and looked around the gate.

羅生門: 雨風の患のない、人目にかかる惧のない、一晩楽にねられそうな所があれば、そこでともかくも、夜を明かそうと思ったからである。
Rashomon: "If there is a place where I won't be bothered by the wind or the rain… a place where I won't be seen… a place where it looks like I can sleep comfortably all night… then I will spend the night there", he thought.

羅生門: すると、幸い門の上の楼へ上る、幅の広い、これも丹を塗った梯子が眼についた。
Rashomon: Luckily, just then, he spotted the wide, red staircase that led to the tower atop the gate.

羅生門: 上なら、人がいたにしても、どうせ死人ばかりである。
Rashomon: The only people he might find up there would already be dead!

羅生門: 下人はそこで、腰にさげた聖柄の太刀が鞘走らないように気をつけながら、藁草履をはいた足を、その梯子の一番下の段へふみかけた。
Rashomon: So, the servant, being careful that his simple wooden-hilted sword did not slip out of its sheath, stepped on the bottom stair with his straw sandal.

羅生門: それから、何分かの後である。
Rashomon: It was a few minutes later.

羅生門: 羅生門の楼の上へ出る、幅の広い梯子の中段に、一人の男が、猫のように身をちぢめて、息を殺しながら、上の容子を窺っていた。
Rashomon: Halfway up the wide staircase leading to the top of the gate's tower, the man held his breath, and, crouching like a cat, he looked up cautiously.

羅生門: 楼の上からさす火の光が、かすかに、その男の右の頬をぬらしている。
Rashomon: The light of a fire shone down softly upon the man's right cheek from the top of the tower.

羅生門: 短い鬚の中に、赤く膿を持った面皰のある頬である。
Rashomon: It was that same cheek, with the red pus-filled pimple among the stubble.

羅生門: 下人は、始めから、この上にいる者は、死人ばかりだと高を括っていた。
Rashomon: The servant had taken for granted that everyone up there would already be dead.

羅生門: それが、梯子を二三段上って見ると、上では誰か火をとぼして、しかもその火をそこここと動かしているらしい。
Rashomon: But when he climbed up two or three more steps, he saw that not only had someone had lit a fire up there, they seemed to be moving it back and forth...

羅生門: これは、その濁った、黄いろい光が、隅々に蜘蛛の巣をかけた天井裏に、揺れながら映ったので、すぐにそれと知れたのである。
Rashomon: He could tell this from the way that the muddy, yellow light wavered in the spider webs hanging from every nook and cranny of the ceiling.

羅生門: この雨の夜に、この羅生門の上で、火をともしているからは、どうせただの者ではない。
Rashomon: A lighted fire… on this rainy night… and on top of this gate… Surely this could be no ordinary human.

羅生門: 下人は、守宮のように足音をぬすんで、やっと急な梯子を、一番上の段まで這うようにして上りつめた。
Rashomon: The servant crept up to the top step of the steep staircase, his feet as silent as a gecko's.

羅生門: そうして体を出来るだけ、平にしながら、頸を出来るだけ、前へ出して、恐る恐る、楼の内を覗いて見た。
Rashomon: He straightened out his body as much as he could, stuck his neck out as far as possible, and cautiously peered into the tower.

羅生門: 見ると、楼の内には、噂に聞いた通り、幾つかの死骸が、無造作に棄ててあるが、火の光の及ぶ範囲が、思ったより狭いので、数は幾つともわからない。
Rashomon: As the rumours had said, a number of corpses had been discarded in the tower, but the firelight wasn't as bright as he had expected, so he couldn't tell how many.

羅生門: ただ、おぼろげながら、知れるのは、その中に裸の死骸と、着物を着た死骸とがあるという事である。
Rashomon: Although the light was dim, what he did know was that some of the bodies were wearing kimonos and others were naked.

羅生門: 勿論、中には女も男もまじっているらしい。
Rashomon: Predictably, the corpses' numbers counted both men and woman, mixed together amongst the dead.

羅生門: そうして、その死骸は皆、それが、かつて、生きていた人間だと云う事実さえ疑われるほど、土を捏ねて造った人形のように、口を開いたり手を延ばしたりして、ごろごろ床の上にころがっていた。
Rashomon: The bodies looked so much like clay dolls, that you might doubt that any of them had ever even been alive. Their mouths open and their arms outstretched, they were strewn haphazardly across the floor.

羅生門: しかも、肩とか胸とかの高くなっている部分に、ぼんやりした火の光をうけて、低くなっている部分の影を一層暗くしながら、永久に唖の如く黙っていた。
Rashomon: And while the higher parts of their bodies—like their chests and shoulders—caught some of the dim firelight, they cast shadows on the lower parts, and the corpses were as eternally silent as a mute.

羅生門: 下人は、それらの死骸の腐爛した臭気に思わず、鼻を掩った。
Rashomon: The servant instinctively covered his nose from the putrid stench of the rotting bodies.

羅生門: しかし、その手は、次の瞬間には、もう鼻を掩う事を忘れていた。
Rashomon: But the next instant, his hand fell away from his face. A strong emotion had almost completely robbed him of his sense of smell.

羅生門: ある強い感情が、ほとんどことごとくこの男の嗅覚を奪ってしまったからだ。
Rashomon: It was at that moment that the servant first caught glimpse of the person squatting among the corpses.

羅生門: 下人の眼は、その時、はじめてその死骸の中に蹲っている人間を見た。
Rashomon: It was an emaciated little old white-haired woman in a dusky-red kimono.

羅生門: 檜皮色の着物を着た、背の低い、痩せた、白髪頭の、猿のような老婆である。
Rashomon: The old woman was carrying a lighted pine torch and staring at one of the corpses' faces.

羅生門: その老婆は、右の手に火をともした松の木片を持って、その死骸の一つの顔を覗きこむように眺めていた。
Rashomon: Judging from the length of its hair in places, it was probably the body of a woman.

羅生門: 髪の毛の長い所を見ると、多分女の死骸であろう。
Rashomon: For a while, moved by six parts fear and four parts curiosity, the servant forgot even to breathe.

羅生門: 下人は、六分の恐怖と四分の好奇心とに動かされて、暫時は呼吸をするのさえ忘れていた。
Rashomon: To borrow a phrase from the writers of the chronicles of old, he felt as if "the hairs on his head and body had grown thick".

羅生門: 旧記の記者の語を借りれば、「頭身の毛も太る」ように感じたのである。
Rashomon: The old woman thrust the handle of the pine torch into the space between the floorboards.

羅生門: すると老婆は、松の木片を、床板の間に挿して、それから、今まで眺めていた死骸の首に両手をかけると、丁度、猿の親が猿の子の虱をとるように、その長い髪の毛を一本ずつ抜きはじめた。
Rashomon: She placed both hands on the corpse's head, and like a monkey picking the lice off its child, she began to pull out strands of the corpse's long hair, one-by-one.

羅生門: 髪は手に従って抜けるらしい。
Rashomon: The hairs seemed to be coming out with very little effort.

羅生門: その髪の毛が、一本ずつ抜けるのに従って、下人の心からは、恐怖が少しずつ消えて行った。
Rashomon: Each time she plucked one of those hairs, the servant grew a little bit less frightened.

羅生門: そうして、それと同時に、この老婆に対するはげしい憎悪が、少しずつ動いて来た。
Rashomon: And each time she plucked one of those hairs, the intense hatred that he now felt for this woman grew a little bit stronger.

羅生門: ――いや、この老婆に対すると云っては、語弊があるかも知れない。
Rashomon: No—it is probably misleading to say that he hated her, per se.

羅生門: むしろ、あらゆる悪に対する反感が、一分毎に強さを増して来たのである。
Rashomon: Rather, it was a revulsion against all forms of evil, which was growing stronger by the minute.

羅生門: この時、誰かがこの下人に、さっき門の下でこの男が考えていた、饑死をするか盗人になるかと云う問題を、改めて持出したら、恐らく下人は、何の未練もなく、饑死を選んだ事であろう。
Rashomon: At that moment, if someone again raised the question that the servant had been thinking about under the gate—whether he would starve to death or become a criminal—the servant would almost certainly have chosen starvation, without an ounce of regret.

羅生門: それほど、この男の悪を憎む心は、老婆の床に挿した松の木片のように、勢いよく燃え上り出していたのである。
Rashomon: Like the torch the old woman had jammed between the floorboards, this was how ardently the man's heart burned against all that was evil.

羅生門: 下人には、勿論、何故老婆が死人の髪の毛を抜くかわからなかった。
Rashomon: The servant, of course, didn't know why the old woman was pulling out the corpse's hair, so, rationally, he had no way of knowing if it was immoral or not.

羅生門: 従って、合理的には、それを善悪のいずれに片づけてよいか知らなかった。
Rashomon: But for this servant, on this rainy night, on top of this gate, pulling out a dead woman's hair was an unforgivable sin.

羅生門: しかし下人にとっては、この雨の夜に、この羅生門の上で、死人の髪の毛を抜くと云う事が、それだけで既に許すべからざる悪であった。
勿論、下人は、さっきまで自分が、盗人になる気でいた事なぞは、とうに忘れていたのである。
Rashomon: Of course, the servant had already forgotten that until very recently, he was considering becoming a robber himself.

羅生門: そこで、下人は、両足に力を入れて、いきなり、梯子から上へ飛び上った。
Rashomon: The servant strained his legs, and, suddenly, leapt up from the stairs without warning.

羅生門: そうして聖柄の太刀に手をかけながら、大股に老婆の前へ歩みよった。
Rashomon: He strode over to the woman, his hand on the wooden hilt of his sword.

羅生門: 老婆が驚いたのは云うまでもない。
Rashomon: Needless to say, the woman was scared out of her wits.

羅生門: 老婆は、一目下人を見ると、まるで弩にでも弾かれたように、飛び上った。
Rashomon: As soon as the old woman saw the servant, she sprung up as if she had been fired from a crossbow.

羅生門: 「おのれ、どこへ行く。
Rashomon: "You! Where are you going?"

羅生門: 」 下人は、老婆が死骸につまずきながら、慌てふためいて逃げようとする行手を塞いで、こう罵った。
Rashomon: The servant shouted. He stood firmly in the old woman's way, as she tripped over corpses in a frenzied attempt to escape.

羅生門: 老婆は、それでも下人をつきのけて行こうとする。
Rashomon: The old woman tried to shove him aside.

羅生門: 下人はまた、それを行かすまいとして、押しもどす。
Rashomon: But the servant still had no intention of letting her go, and he pushed her back.

羅生門: 二人は死骸の中で、しばらく、無言のまま、つかみ合った。
Rashomon: For a while, the two grappled among the corpses without saying a word.

羅生門: しかし勝敗は、はじめからわかっている。
Rashomon: But the outcome of this battle was clear from the beginning.

羅生門: 下人はとうとう、老婆の腕をつかんで、無理にそこへ扭じ倒した。
Rashomon: In the end, the servant grabbed the old woman's arm and wrenched her down to the floor.

羅生門: 丁度、鶏の脚のような、骨と皮ばかりの腕である。
Rashomon: Her arm, like a chicken leg, was merely skin and bones. "What were you doing?

羅生門: 「何をしていた。
Rashomon: Well, what were you doing?

羅生門: 云え。
Rashomon: SPEAK!

羅生門: 云わぬと、これだぞよ。
Rashomon: If you don't tell me, you'll get THIS!"

羅生門: 」 下人は、老婆をつき放すと、いきなり、太刀の鞘を払って、白い鋼の色をその眼の前へつきつけた。
Rashomon: The servant pushed the old woman away from him, and, suddenly, he drew his sword and thrust the pale white steel before her eyes.

羅生門: けれども、老婆は黙っている。
Rashomon: But the old woman said nothing.
